metaData.descriptionCS: The examinee solves math calculation problems in the Response Booklet.

questions.title: Item 1. How many balls are there?

data.message: Point to Item 1 and say, Here are some balls. Count them. How many balls are there?

questions.title: Item 2. Write the number of balls.

data.message: Point to the box beside Item 2 and say, Write that number here. Write the number of balls you counted.

scoreButtons.label: Penalize for reversed and unrecognizable numbers.

data.message: Point to Item 3 and say, Here are some letters and numbers. Draw a circle around each number. Circle only the numbers.

questions.title: Item 4. Draw a circle around the group of 6 triangles.

data.message: Point to each box in Item 4 and say, Here are groups of triangles. Draw a circle around the group of 6 triangles.

questions.title: Item 5. Write the number that was left out.

data.message: Point to Item 5 and say, Here are numbers from 1 to 10, but one number has been left out. Point to the blank line. Write the number that was left out.

questions.title: Item 6. Point to the one that means “add” or “plus.”

data.message: Sweep your finger from left to right across the row for Items 6–7 and say, Look at each of these. Point to the one that means “add” or “plus.”

questions.title: Item 7. Point to the one that means “subtract” or “take away.”

data.message: Again, sweep your finger from left to right across the row for Items 6–7 and say, Look at each of these again. Point to the one that means “subtract” or “take away.”

For Grades K-1 only: Say, Now I want you to solve some math problems. Point to the Item 8 in the Response Booklet and say, Start here and work the problems in this order. Sweep your finger from left to right across the first row and then across the next row. Say, If you come to a problem you don’t know, just skip it. If you finish this page, turn to the next page. Tell me when you’re finished.

If the student needs help reading any words, read those words aloud to the student; do not help with number problems.

1 + 1

For Grades 2-4 only: To begin administration, give the student a pencil without an eraser and say, You will be using a pencil without an eraser, so if you make a mistake, just cross it out. Open the Response Booklet to Item 14 of Numerical Operations and hand it to the student.

Say, I want you to solve some math problems. Point to the Item 14 in the Response Booklet and say, Start here and work the problems in this order. Sweep your finger from left to right across the first row and then across the next row. Say, If you come to a problem you don’t know, just skip it. If you finish this page, turn to the next page. Tell me when you’re finished.

If the student needs help reading any words, read those words aloud to the student; do not help with number problems.

3 - 1

For Grades 5-12+ only: To begin administration, give the student a pencil without an eraser and say, You will be using a pencil without an eraser, so if you make a mistake, just cross it out. Open the Response Booklet to Item 18 of Numerical Operations and hand it to the student.

Say, I want you to solve some math problems. Point to the Item 18 in the Response Booklet and say, Start here and work the problems in this order. Sweep your finger from left to right across the first row and then across the next row. Say, If you come to a problem you don’t know, just skip it. If you finish this page, turn to the next page. Tell me when you’re finished.

If the student needs help reading any words, read those words aloud to the student; do not help with number problems.

12 - 5

questions.title: Item 48. solve for x and y

scoreButtons.label: Solves all three: AB = 12  BC = 12  AC = 6
Solves all three: tan A = 4/3  sin B = 3/5  cos A = 3/5
